description:
Actinomyces slackii is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Actinomyces. Actinomyces bacteria are Gram-positive, anaerobic or facultatively anaerobic, and form branching, filamentous structures. 

Actinomyces slackii was first isolated from the human oral cavity, specifically from dental plaque samples. It is considered a commensal bacterium, meaning it is commonly found in the normal human microbiome without causing disease in healthy individuals.

This species is characterized by its ability to form dense, chalky white colonies when cultured in the laboratory. Actinomyces slackii is capable of metabolizing a variety of carbohydrates and can produce lactic acid as a byproduct of its fermentative metabolism.

While Actinomyces slackii is not typically associated with causing infections, it has been occasionally isolated from clinical samples in cases of actinomycosis, a rare and chronic infectious disease characterized by the formation of abscesses and granulomatous lesions. However, its precise role in the pathogenesis of actinomycosis remains an area of ongoing research.
prompt: Provide a short scientific description of this species: Actinomyces slackii
